Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment and reasonableness of RPD decision
Procedural_Context: Judicial review under s 72(1) of IRPA
Credibility_Assessment: RPD questioned applicant's credibility due to inconsistencies, lack of corroboration, and re-availment of state protection
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, lack of documentary corroboration
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution as a Kurd in Turkey
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible supporting evidence and inconsistencies in testimony
Proceeding_Type: Refugee claim and subsequent judicial review
Review_Outcome: No reviewable error found; RPD decision upheld
Application_Factor: Applicant's return to Turkey and use of state services
Authority: Refugee Protection Division, Federal Court on review
Decision_Review_Issue: Was the RPD's credibility assessment reasonable?
Governing_Rule_or_Provision: IRPA s 72(1), principles of administrative law on standard of review
Cause_of_Refusal: Insufficient evidence to support persecution claims, credibility concerns
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of corroborative evidence, inconsistent testimony
Credibility_Issues: Yes – inconsistencies, lack of corroboration, re-availment of protection
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Challenge to RPD's credibility findings on judicial review
Jurisdictional_Focus: Canada – Federal Court review of RPD decision
Relevant_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, administrative law on standard of review
Procedural_Issue: Compliance with judicial review requirements under IRPA
Omission_Type: Failure to provide sufficient corroborating evidence
